title: Replace your VPN
description: Give users secure, auditable network and application access.
detailed_description: This tutorial will show you how to use a combination of Cloudflare products to address use cases typically served by a VPN. Cloudflare provides discrete, Zero Trust enabled application and service access to all TCP and UDP ports in both on-premise and cloud networks. We do this using a combination of an endpoint agent and a network connector, but no other software or hardware is required for this deployment. Additionally, security policy is enforced at the Cloudflare edge and managed in your dashboard.

elements.description: Concepts explain the basic ideas behind how Cloudflare Zero Trust works.

elements.title: Review prerequisites
elements.description:
Make sure that you have the following:

  1. A device that can run WARP, Cloudflare's endpoint agent.
  2. A private network with applications or services that are available locally or via a VPN.
  3. A host server that can run the lightweight Cloudflare Tunnel daemon process (requirements).
  4. The ability for that host server to connect to the Internet on the required ports and to connect locally to the private network applications.

pages.additional_description: If you have a Cloudflare contact (Enterprise only), ask them to set up your account as a multi-user organization after you finish this step.

pages.link_title: (Optional) Add public domains and subdomains to Cloudflare
pages.additional_description: You will use these domains to test agentless access to web services. Alternatively, you could purchase a new testing domain through Cloudflare Registrar.
The team name is used to create a unique subdomain for your application portal.

elements.title: Connect private network to Cloudflare
elements.description: Cloudflare Tunnel connects applications and services to Cloudflareâ€™s network. Cloudflare Tunnel is an outbound-only daemon service that can run on nearly any host machine and proxies local traffic once validated from the Cloudflare network.

pages.additional_description: Cloudflare Tunnel will run on a host locally in your network and make a persistent, outbound QUIC connection to Cloudflare.

pages.link_title: Create private network routes in Cloudflare Tunnel
pages.additional_description: Routes determine which private IP addresses are available to users in your Zero Trust organization. It's okay to make these routes relatively wide, since you can add granular security control with Zero Trust policies.
While the Cloudflare Tunnel will advertise a relatively broad range, you can restrict network access by user identity, device posture, domain request, IP, port, protocol, and more.

elements.title: Agentless access to private web services
elements.description:
Cloudflare supports Zero Trust, identity-aware access to internal HTTP applications without the need to use a device client. This step will require an active DNS zone on Cloudflare in the same account in which you are building your Zero Trust policies.

Performing these tasks in this order makes sure your private application is never accessible via the public Internet.

elements.title: Connect user devices to Cloudflare
elements.description:
The WARP client encrypts designated traffic from a user's device to Cloudflare's edge. It can run alongside other VPN clients so long as there are no route conflicts.

This setup uses a positive security model, meaning that only certain IP ranges or domains (local or external) are proxied through Cloudflare's network. Most admins test by downloading the client and authenticating in, but you can also install WARP via Managed deployments.

pages.additional_description: With device enrollment rules, you define which users can connect devices to your Zero Trust organization.
We recommend manually deploying the client during your pilot and revisiting automated deployments during implementation.
This will allow WARP to build a Wireguard-based, encrypted tunnel on your device to route traffic to Cloudflare.
For initial testing, users should manually authenticate the client to their organizationâ€™s Cloudflare Zero Trust instance.

This will determine what traffic WARP does and does not proxy.

If you added private network routes in the 10.0.0.0 range, ensure that these IP addresses are included in WARP.
These policies allow Cloudflare to proxy requests to internal or private infrastructure without a public DNS record.

pages.additional_description: Review your Gateway logs to make sure traffic is reaching the edge.
